text: Ã  tÃ´i hiá»ƒu rá»“i, váº¥n Ä‘á» lÃ  náº¿u tÃ´i chÆ°a dÃ¹ng lá»‡nh open nÃ o thÃ¬ ko sÃ i Ä‘c skill vá»›i Workflow táº¡i vÃ¬ chÆ°a biáº¿t tÃ´i á»Ÿ Ä‘Ã¢u Ä‘Ãºng ko

Clarifying the Path Issue
I'm now zeroing in on a crucial point. While it's true /open is the typical signal, I'm thinking about edge cases. Ideally, AntigravityBridge.getCurrentProjectRoot() should, through the Chrome DevTools Protocol, be able to identify the current path, regardless of a prior /open command. It's a matter of ensuring the system can always detect the working directory.
Confirming the Detection Logic
I'm now refining the logic behind project root detection. It seems /open via the bot is contingent on VS Code having an open folder, but vscode.workspace.workspaceFolders is intermittently empty. Therefore, automated detection through the Chrome DevTools Protocol is failing, and I need a fallback. The current system relies on manual input via /open or /setproject, making manual declaration crucial. I need to verify that I've understood this correctly. I'm also exploring the possibility of extracting the project root from the VS Code window title as an alternative.
Analyzing Title Data
I've been examining the potential for extracting project roots from the VS Code window title as a fallback. It seems the format varies (e.g., AntiTelegram - Antigravity - README.md vs. default VS Code) which is problematic. I had thought AntiTelegram was the project name, but it is a folder. Ultimately, the title only gives the project name not the full path, and without a /open command, I'm blind to the actual disk location.
html:
Clarifying the Path Issue

I'm now zeroing in on a crucial point. While it's true 

/open
is the typical signal, I'm thinking about edge cases. Ideally, 
AntigravityBridge.getCurrentProjectRoot()
should, through the Chrome DevTools Protocol, be able to identify the current path, regardless of a prior 
/open
command. It's a matter of ensuring the system can always detect the working directory.

Confirming the Detection Logic

I'm now refining the logic behind project root detection. It seems 

/open
via the bot is contingent on VS Code having an open folder, but 
vscode.workspace.workspaceFolders
is intermittently empty. Therefore, automated detection through the Chrome DevTools Protocol is failing, and I need a fallback. The current system relies on manual input via 
/open
or 
/setproject
, making manual declaration crucial. I need to verify that I've understood this correctly. I'm also exploring the possibility of extracting the project root from the VS Code window title as an alternative.

Analyzing Title Data

I've been examining the potential for extracting project roots from the VS Code window title as a fallback. It seems the format varies (e.g., 

AntiTelegram - Antigravity - README.md
vs. default VS Code) which is problematic. I had thought 
AntiTelegram
was the project name, but it is a folder. Ultimately, the title only gives the project name not the full path, and without a 
/open
command, I'm blind to the actual disk location.
